Paragraph: Reduced nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide phosphate - diaphorase ( NADPH - d ) histochemistry was also employed to visualize NOS as an index of enzyme expression in mice brain regions related to motor control .

Let's think step by step.

| Chemical |
| --- |
| Reduced nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide phosphate (NADPH) |
| Nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide phosphate - diaphorase (NADPH-d) |
| Nitric oxide synthase (NOS) |

Please remove entities that do not clearly refer to "Chemical" and present the valid entities as a Markdown table with one column "Chemical".

Make sure to present the entities precisely in the same words as in the original paragraph.

| Chemical |
| --- |
| Reduced nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide phosphate (NADPH) |
| Nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide phosphate - diaphorase (NADPH-d) |
| Nitric oxide synthase (NOS) |

Note: In this context, NADPH is a reduced form of nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide phosphate, which is a chemical cofactor involved in various redox reactions in the body. NADPH-d is an enzyme, specifically an isoform of diaphorase that uses NADPH as a cofactor. NOS is an enzyme that synthesizes nitric oxide, a signaling molecule. Both NADPH and NADPH-d are considered chemicals, while NOS is an enzyme that uses chemicals as substrates to produce another chemical (nitric oxide).
